quest_title: The vector sum of two unit vectors is a unit vector then the magnitude of the difference is
explanation_txt:
Vector sum of two unit vectors is equal to unit vector so angle is 120°.

\(\begin{aligned} \therefore \text { Difference } &=\sqrt{1^{2}-2.1 .1 \cos 120^{\circ}+1^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{1^{2}+1+1}=\sqrt{3} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A stone is thrown at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal reaches a maximum height \(H\). Then the time of flight of stone will be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { H = \cfrac { u ^ { 2 } \sin ^ { 2 } \theta } { 2 g } \text { and } T = \cfrac { 2 u \sin \theta } { g } \Rightarrow T ^ { 2 } = \cfrac { 4 u ^ { 2 } \sin ^ { 2 } \theta } { g ^ { 2 } } } \\ { \therefore \cfrac { T ^ { 2 } } { H } = \cfrac { 8 } { g } \Rightarrow T = \sqrt { \cfrac { 8 H } { g } } = 2 \sqrt { \cfrac { 2 H } { g } } } \end{array}\)

quest_title: Two satellites A and B of masses m\({}_{A}\) and m\({}_{B}\) where m\({}_{B}\) = 2m\({}_{A}\) are moving in circular orbits of radii r\({}_{A}\) and r\({}_{B}\) where r\({}_{B}\) = 4r\({}_{A}\) around earth. The time period of A is 4h then time period of B is
explanation_txt:
\(\left(\cfrac{T_{B}}{T_{A}}\right)^{2}=\left(\cfrac{r_{B}}{r_{A}}\right)^{3}=64\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{B}}=8 \times 4=32 \, \mathrm{hrs}\)

quest_title: The rear side of a truck is open and a box of mass 20kg is placed on the truck at 4m away from open end. The coefficient of friction between box & truck is 0.15 & truck start to accelerate at 2m/s\({}^{2}\) then box will fall off the truck after travelling a distance.
explanation_txt:
Force on box \((\mathrm{F})=\mathrm{ma}=20 \times 2=40 \mathrm{N}\)
Now for box,
\(\mathrm{F}-\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{f}}=\mathrm{ma}^{\prime}\)

or, \(40-\mu \mathrm{mg}=20 \mathrm{a}^{\prime}\)
or, \(\mathrm{a}^{\prime}=\cfrac{40-0.15 \times 20 \times 10}{20}=0.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{S}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{a}^{\prime} \mathrm{t}^{2}\)

or, \(t=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 s}{a^{\prime}}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \times 4}{0.5}}=4 \mathrm{sec}\)
For Truck,
\(S_{t}=\cfrac{1}{2} a t^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 4^{2}=16 \mathrm{m}\)

quest_title: The threshold wavelength of metal surface is 2730\(\mathring{A}\). The stopping potential for ultraviolet radiation of wavelength 1800\(\mathring{A}\) is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{KE}=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda}-\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda_{0}}\)
\(=6.62 \times 10^{34} \times 3 \times 10^{8}\left(\cfrac{1}{1800 \times 10^{-10}}-\cfrac{1}{2730 \times 10^{-10}}\right)\)
\(=3.76 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{J}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{KE}}{\mathrm{e}}=\cfrac{3.76 \times 10^{-19}}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}}=2.3 \mathrm{V}\)
question_plain_title: The threshold wavelength of metal surface is 2730. The stopping potential for ultraviolet radiation of wavelength 1800 is

quest_title: A sample of Ra -226 has half life of 1620 years. What is the mass of the sample which undergoes 20,000 dis/sec? (N = 6.02\(\times\)10\({}^{23}\) mol\({}^{-1}\))
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{A}=\lambda \mathrm{N}\)
\(\mathrm{N}=\cfrac{20000}{0.693} \times \mathrm{T}_{1 / 2}\)
\(\quad=\cfrac{20000}{0.693} \times 1620 \times 365 \times 24 \times 3600\)
\(\quad=1.47 \times 10^{15}\)
Mass \(=\cfrac{226}{6.02 \times 10^{23}} \times 1.47 \times 10^{15}\)
\(\qquad=5.5 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{g}\)

quest_title: Find equivalent capacitance between \(\text{A}\) and \(\text{B}\).
explanation_txt:
The network can be redrawn as wheatstone bridge which is balanced here.
\(C_{1}=\cfrac{4 \times 4}{4+4}=2\)
\(C_{2}=\cfrac{4 \times 4}{4+4}=2\)
\(\begin{align} \therefore \quad & C_{A B}=C_{1}+C_{2} \\ & C_{A B}=2+2 \\ & C_{AB} = 4 \mu F\end{align}\)

\(T=B I N A \sin \theta \)
\(\theta=90^{\circ} \)
\(T=B I N A \)
when \(\theta\) is the angle b/w O magnetic field and then
\(T=0.1 \times 0.1 \times 100 \times\left(10 \times 10^{-2}\right) \times\left(4 \times 10^{-2}\right) \)
\(T=4 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{Nm} \)

quest_title: A coil wound on a transformer of rectangular cross-section. If all the linear dimensions of the transformer are increased by a factor 2 and no. of turns per unit length of coil remains the same, the self-inductance increases by a factor of
explanation_txt:
\(L=\cfrac{\mu_{0} \pi N^{2} A}{l}=\mu_{0}\left(\cfrac{N}{l}\right)^{2} \times A l \)
\(\text { where } \cfrac{N}{l}=\text { constant } \)
When linear dimension is increased by factor \(2,\) area becomes 4 times and length \(\text { becomes }^{\prime} 2^{\prime}\) times. Therefore self inductance becomes ' 8 'times.

quest_title: If \( \cfrac { \tan 3 \theta - 1 } { \tan 3 \theta + 1 } = \sqrt { 3 } \) , then the general value of \( \theta \) is
explanation_txt:
\( \begin{array} { l } { \cfrac { \tan 3 \theta - 1 } { \tan 3 \theta + 1 } = \sqrt { 3 } } \\ { \Rightarrow \cfrac { \tan 3 \theta - \tan ( \pi / 4 ) } { 1 + \tan 3 \theta \cdot \tan ( \pi / 4 ) } = \sqrt { 3 } \Rightarrow \tan \left( 3 \theta - \cfrac { \pi } { 4 } \right) = \tan \cfrac { \pi } { 3 } } \\ { \Rightarrow 3 \theta - ( \pi / 4 ) = n \pi + ( \pi / 3 ) } \end{array} \)

\( \Rightarrow 3 \theta = n \pi + \cfrac { 7 \pi } { 12 } \Rightarrow \theta = \cfrac { n \pi } { 3 } + \cfrac { 7 \pi } { 36 } \)

quest_title: The distance between the directrices of the ellipse \(\cfrac { x ^ { 2 } } { 36 } + \cfrac { y ^ { 2 } } { 20 } = 1\) is
explanation_txt:
From the equation, \( a = 6, b = 2 \sqrt 5 \)

We know, \( e = \sqrt{1 - \cfrac{b^2}{a^2}} = \sqrt{1 - \cfrac{20}{36}} = \sqrt{1 - \cfrac{5}{9}} = \cfrac{2}{3}\)

The distance between directrices is \( 2\cfrac{a}{e} = 2 \cfrac{6 \times 3}{2} = 18 \)

quest_title: For what value of \(k\) will the equation \(x^{2} -(3k-1)x+\)\(2k^{2} +2k\) have equal roots ?
explanation_txt:
For the equation to be real roots, \(b^{2} -4ac=0\)

\[\Rightarrow (3k-1)^{2} =4(2k^{2} +2k-11)\]

\[\Rightarrow 9k^{2} +1-6k=8k^{2} +8k-44\]

\[\Rightarrow k^{2} -14k+45=0 \]

\[ \Rightarrow (k-5)(k-9) = 0\]

\(k=5\)or \(k=9\).

explanation_plain_text:
For the equation to be real roots,

or .

quest_title: If three points A, B, C are collinear, whose position vectors are \(i-{\rm 2}j-{\rm 8}k{\rm ,}\, \, {\rm 5}i-{\rm 2}k\) and \(11\, i+\, 3\, j+7k\) respectively, then the ratio in which B divides AC is
explanation_txt:
Let the B divide AC in ratio \(\lambda :1\), then

\[5i-2k=\cfrac{\lambda (11i+3j+7k)+i-2j-8k}{\lambda +1} \]

\(\Rightarrow 3\lambda -2=0\) \(\Rightarrow \lambda =\cfrac{2}{3} \) i.e., ratio = 2 : 3.

quest_title: The area enclosed by \( y = x^3 - 7x - 6 \) and the \(X\) axis is:
explanation_txt:
Let, \( f(x) = x^3-7x-6 = x^3 - 9x + 2x - 6 = x(x-3)(x+3)+2(x-3) = (x+2)(x-3)(x+1) \)

To find the points of intersection with \(X\) axis, \( f(x) = 0 \Rightarrow x=-2,-1,3 \)

\( f(x) \) is positive in \( (-2,-1) \) and negative in \( (-1,3) \). So, integrating from \(-2\) to \(3\) gives difference of areas bounded by \(f(x)\) and \(X\) axis in these intervals.

What we need is a sum. So,

\( A = \left| \int_{-2}^{-1} f(x) dx \right| + \left| \int_{-1}^{3} f(x) dx \right| \\ A = \left| \int_{-2}^{-1} (x^3 - 7x - 6) dx \right|+ \left| \int_{-1}^{3} (x^3 - 7x - 6) dx \right| \\ A = \left| \cfrac{x^4}{4} - \cfrac{7x^2}{2} - 6x \right|_{-2}^{-1} + \left| \cfrac{x^4}{4} - \cfrac{7x^2}{2} - 6x \right|_{-1}^{-3} \)

Simplifying gives \( A = \cfrac{131}{4} \)

is positive in and negative in . So, integrating from to gives difference of areas bounded by and axis in these intervals.

quest_title: An aeroplane is moving in a circular path with speed 200 Km/hr. The change in velocity in half revolution is
explanation_txt:
Change in velocity

\(\begin{aligned} v_{\mathrm{R}} &=\sqrt{v^{2}-2 v^{2} \cos 180^{\circ}+v^{2}}=\sqrt{2 v^{2}+2 v^{2}} \\ &=2 v=2 \times 200=400 \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A particle experience constant acceleration for 20 sec after starting from rest. It travels a distance S\({}_{1}\) in first 10 sec and a distance S\({}_{2}\) in next 10 sec then
explanation_txt:
First case
\(\mathrm{s}_{1}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{a}(10)^{2}=50 \mathrm{a} \)

Second case
\(u=10 a \)
\(s_{2}=10 a \times 10+\cfrac{1}{2} a(10)^{2} \)

\(\quad=100 a+50 a \)
\(\quad=150 a \)
\(\quad=3 s_{1} \)

\(\therefore \mathrm{s}_{2}=3 \mathrm{s}_{1}\)

quest_title: Simple pendulum has time period T with brass bob. The bob is now immersed in liquid of density \(\cfrac{1}{10} \) \({}^{th}\) of brass and liquid is non viscous then time period will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{T}=2 \pi \sqrt{\cfrac{l}{g}}\)

In liquid,

Apparant weight \((mg')=\mathrm{V} \rho \mathrm{g}-\mathrm{V} \cfrac{\rho}{10} \mathrm{g}\)

\(\qquad = \cfrac{9}{10} \mathrm{v} \rho \mathrm{g}=\cfrac{9}{10} \mathrm{mg}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{g}^{\prime}=\cfrac{9}{10} \mathrm{g}\)
\(\therefore \cfrac{T^{\prime}}{T}=\sqrt{\cfrac{g}{g^{\prime}}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{g}{\cfrac{9g}{10}}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{10}{9}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{T}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\cfrac{10}{9}} \mathrm{T}\)

quest_title: A convex lens of focal length 40 cm is in contact with a concave lens of focal length 25 cm. The power of combination is
explanation_txt:
Focal length of the combination can be calculated as \(\cfrac{1}{F} =\cfrac{1}{f_{1} } +\cfrac{1}{f_{2} } \Rightarrow \cfrac{1}{F} =\cfrac{1}{(+40)} +\cfrac{1}{(-25)} \Rightarrow F=-\cfrac{200}{3} cm =-0.666 m\)

\(\therefore P=\cfrac{1}{F} =\cfrac{1}{-0.666} =-1.5\; D\)

quest_title: A point light source is suspended above the centre of a circular table radius r. In order to produce, the maximum illuminance at the edges of table the height of light source is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{e}}=\cfrac{\operatorname{Icos} \theta}{\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{r}^{2}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{Ih}}{\left(\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{r}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}\)

To have maximum illuminance \(\cfrac{\mathrm{dE}}{\mathrm{dh}}=0\)

or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{dh}}\left\{\cfrac{\mathrm{h}}{\left(\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{r}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}\right\}=0\)

\(\left(\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{r}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}+\mathrm{h}(-3 / 2)\left(\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{r}^{2}\right)^{-5 / 2} \cdot 2 \mathrm{h}=0\)

\(\cfrac{\mathrm{h}}{\left(\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{r}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}=\cfrac{3 \mathrm{h}^{2}}{\left(\mathrm{h}^{2}+\mathrm{r}^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}} \\ \therefore \mathrm{h}=\cfrac{\mathrm{r}}{\sqrt{2}}\)

quest_title: At \(20^{o} C,\) the \(Ag^{+} \) ion concentration in a saturated solution of \(Ag_{2} CrO_{4} \) is \(1.5\times 10^{-4} \, mole/litre.\) At \(20^{o} C,\) the solubility product of \(Ag_{2} CrO_{4} \) would be
explanation_txt:
\(AgCrO_{4} \) \(\mathrm{\rightleftharpoons}\) \({\mathop{2Ag^{+} }\limits_{(2S)^{2} }} +{\mathop{CrO_{4}^{-} }\limits_{S\, \, \, }} \)

\(K_{sp} =4S^{3} \)

Given \(2S=1.5\times 10^{-4} \)

\[\therefore \, K_{sp} =(2S)^{2} \times S\] \[=(1.5\times 10^{-4} )^{2} \times \left(\cfrac{1.5\times 10^{-4} }{2} \right) =1.6875\times 10^{-12} \]

quest_title: A capacitor of capacitance \(\text{C}\) is fully charged to a 200 V supply. It is then discharged through a small coil of resistance wire embedded in thermally insulated block of specific heat 2.5 \(\times\) 10\({}^{2}\) J/kg K and of mass 0.1 kg. If the temperature of block rises by 0.4 K, the value of \(\text{C}\) is
explanation_txt:
The energy stored in capacitor is given by:

\(U=\cfrac{1}{2} C V^{2}\)

\(U=\cfrac{1}{2} C \times(200)^{2}=2 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{C}\) Joule

This energy is used to heat up the block. Let do be rise in temperature, then

\(\begin{array}{l}{m s d \theta=0.1 \times 2.5 \times 10^{2} \times 0.4} \\ {\text { Now, } 2 \times 10^{4} \times C=10} \\ {\Rightarrow C=500 \mu \mathrm{F}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: The magnetic induction at a point \(\textit{P}\) which is distant 4 \(\textit{cm}\) from a long current carrying wire is \(10^{-8} \, Tesla\). The field of induction at a distance 12 \(\textit{cm}\) from the same current would be
explanation_txt:
\(B=\cfrac{\mu _{0} }{4\pi } \cdot \cfrac{2I}{r} \)

\(B \propto \cfrac{1}{r}\)

\(\Rightarrow\)\(\cfrac{B_{1} }{B_{2} } =\cfrac{r_{2} }{r_{1} } \)

\(\Rightarrow\)\(\cfrac{10^{-8} }{B_{2} } =\cfrac{12}{4} \)

\[\Rightarrow B_{2} =3.33\times 10^{-9} \, Tesla\]

\(I_{0}=\sqrt{2} \times I_{r m s}=\sqrt{2} \times 5 \)
\(I_{0}=\sqrt{2} \times I_{r m s}=7.07 \mathrm{Amp} \approx 7 \mathrm{Amp} \)
